data.title: Topic: Horse training & racing
data.text:
A young farm boy enlists to serve in World War I after his beloved horse is sold to the cavalry. His hopeful journey takes him out of England and onto the front lines as the war rages on.

War Horse is a 2011 film directed by Steven Spielberg, based on the novel by Michael Morpurgo. It portrays the deep bond between a young man named Albert and his horse Joey during World War I. The movie emphasizes the resilience of the human spirit and the unbreakable connection between humans and horses even in the most challenging circumstances. It beautifully illustrates the loyalty and trust that can develop between humans and horses, showcasing their emotional connection amid the chaos of war.

Seabiscuit is a 2003 film directed by Gary Ross, based on the true story of the racehorse Seabiscuit. The movie explores the power of redemption and hope as it chronicles the unlikely rise of Seabiscuit from an underdog to a racing legend. It also highlights the symbiotic relationship between the horse, jockey, and owner, showing how they form a close-knit team working towards a common goal. The film captures the resilience of both human and equine spirit in the face of adversity.

This is the 1939 adaptation of the Seabiscuit story, and it, too, conveys the inspirational journey of the undersized and underestimated racehorse to become a symbol of hope during the Great Depression. While the storytelling might differ from the 2003 version, the core theme of the bond between humans and horses remains consistent. It reflects the historical significance of Seabiscuit and his impact on American culture during a challenging period.

Black Beauty is a 2020 adaptation of the classic novel by Anna Sewell. This modern retelling of the story is seen through the eyes of a wild mustang named Beauty and her connection with a young girl named Jo. The film explores themes of freedom, friendship, and the resilience of spirit, both in the horse and the human. It portrays the healing power of the bond between a horse and a human, showcasing how they can bring positive change into each other's lives.

The 1994 adaptation of Black Beauty is a timeless tale of a beautiful black horse and his various owners throughout his life. It serves as a classic representation of the enduring bond between humans and horses. The film emphasizes the horse's perspective, allowing viewers to witness the world through Black Beauty's eyes and experience the various relationships he forms with his owners, highlighting the different aspects of the human-horse connection throughout his lifetime.

The Black Stallion Returns is the sequel to the 1979 film The Black Stallion. It continues the story of Alec Ramsey and his horse, the Black. The film takes them on an adventure across the Arabian desert in search of the Black's mysterious origins. The movie showcases the deep bond and trust between Alec and his horse as they face challenging and dangerous situations together. It highlights the idea that horses can be not just companions but also partners in grand adventures.

Hidalgo is based on the true story of Frank T. Hopkins, a cowboy and long-distance rider, and his mustang, Hidalgo. The film explores the endurance and determination of both horse and rider as they compete in a grueling 3,000-mile race across the Arabian desert. It portrays the mutual reliance and partnership between Frank and Hidalgo as they overcome cultural barriers and adversity. The movie emphasizes the idea that a strong bond between a human and a horse can enable them to conquer extraordinary challenges.

Jappeloup is a French film based on the true story of the show jumping horse Jappeloup and his rider, Pierre Durand. The movie delves into the world of equestrian sports and the intense dedication required to excel in show jumping. It highlights the trust and teamwork between Pierre and Jappeloup as they strive to become champions on the international stage. The film underscores the sacrifices made for the love of the sport and the connection between a rider and their horse, demonstrating that success in equestrian sports is built on mutual understanding and partnership.

Flicka 2 is a family-oriented film that centers around the bond between a teenage girl named Carrie and a wild mustang named Flicka. The movie explores themes of friendship, trust, and perseverance as Carrie works to tame Flicka and train her for competition. It underscores the idea that horses can serve as both challenges and sources of inspiration in a person's life. The film shows how patience and determination can lead to a deep connection between a horse and its owner, even when faced with initial resistance and wild behavior.

Ostwind, a German film, tells the story of a young girl named Mika who forms a strong bond with a wild stallion named Ostwind. The movie emphasizes the transformative power of the human-horse connection. It portrays how Mika's determination and love for Ostwind lead her to discover her own inner strength and overcome challenges. The film celebrates the idea that horses can be not only companions but also catalysts for personal growth and self-discovery.

Free Rein is a series that follows the adventures of a teenager named Zoe who spends her summer on a horse ranch in England. The show explores themes of friendship, freedom, and the unique connection between humans and horses. It depicts how Zoe's life changes as she forms bonds with the horses on the ranch, particularly with a wild horse named Raven. The series highlights the idea that horses have the ability to touch our lives in unexpected ways, leading to personal growth and meaningful relationships.

Flicka: Country Pride is another installment in the Flicka series. It follows the story of a young girl named Kelly and her relationship with a wild mustang named Flicka. The film explores themes of family, tradition, and the special bond between humans and horses. It portrays how Kelly and Flicka work together to save their family's ranch. The movie highlights the importance of preserving the heritage of horsemanship and the enduring connection between generations of horse lovers.

Dreamer is a heartwarming film based on the true story of the racehorse Mariah's Storm and her remarkable recovery from a career-threatening injury. The movie showcases the determination of a young girl named Cale and her family as they believe in Mariah's potential for a second chance at racing. It underscores the idea that horses can inspire hope, dreams, and the belief in the extraordinary. The film celebrates the human-horse bond and the healing power of faith and perseverance.

Cowgirls 'n Angels is a film that explores the world of rodeo and the relationship between a young girl named Ida and a mysterious horseman named Terence. The movie delves into themes of identity, belonging, and the pursuit of one's dreams. It portrays how Ida's determination to find her rodeo-performer father leads her to discover her passion for horsemanship. The film emphasizes the sense of community and mentorship that can exist within the equestrian world and how horses can guide individuals towards self-discovery and personal fulfillment.

Young Black Stallion is a prequel to the 1979 film The Black Stallion. It tells the story of the Black Stallion's early years and his bond with a young girl named Neera. The film explores the beauty of the Arabian desert and the profound connection between Neera and the stallion. It portrays the growth of trust and friendship as they navigate the challenges of the desert together. The movie celebrates the idea that horses can be both companions and sources of adventure, especially in the enchanting backdrop of the desert.

Secretariat is a biographical drama that tells the incredible story of the legendary racehorse Secretariat, who became the first Triple Crown winner in 25 years. The film focuses on the relationship between Secretariat and his owner, Penny Chenery, highlighting her determination to defy gender stereotypes in the male-dominated horse racing industry. It portrays the unwavering belief in Secretariat's potential and the bond between the horse and those who believed in him. The movie underscores the idea that horses can be symbols of inspiration and hope, breaking records and barriers along the way.

The Horse Whisperer, directed by and starring Robert Redford, is a film that explores the art of horse training and the healing power of human understanding. The movie follows the story of a teenage girl named Grace and her traumatized horse, Pilgrim, who are both injured in a tragic accident. It introduces Tom Booker, a horse whisperer who helps Grace and Pilgrim heal physically and emotionally. The film highlights the importance of patience, empathy, and communication in the world of horse training. It portrays how horses can mirror the emotional states of their human counterparts and how trust and healing can be achieved through mutual understanding.

The Rider is a contemporary film that blurs the lines between fiction and reality. It tells the story of a young rodeo rider, Brady Blackburn, who faces a career-ending injury. The film explores themes of identity, resilience, and the deep connection between a cowboy and his horses. It showcases the emotional bond Brady shares with his horses, particularly with a horse named Apollo. The movie illustrates how horses are not just partners in rodeo but also integral parts of a cowboy's way of life. It emphasizes the challenges and sacrifices that come with the equestrian profession and the enduring relationship between a rider and his horses.

Dream Alliance is an unlikely race horse bred by small-town Welsh bartender Jan Vokes. With no experience, Jan convinces her neighbors to chip in their meager earnings to help raise Dream in the hopes he can compete with the racing elites.

Dream Horse is based on the true story of a Welsh bartender named Jan Vokes who forms a syndicate with her fellow villagers to breed and race a racehorse named Dream Alliance. The film explores themes of community, ambition, and the unlikely dream of owning a racehorse. It portrays the determination and camaraderie of the villagers as they invest their time and resources in pursuing their horse racing dreams. The movie underscores the idea that horses can bring people from diverse backgrounds together and provide a sense of purpose and excitement. It celebrates the power of collective effort and the joy of seeing an underdog horse succeed against the odds.

Lean on Pete is a drama film that follows the journey of a young boy named Charley and his bond with a quarter horse named Lean on Pete. The movie explores themes of survival, friendship, and the harsh realities of life. It portrays Charley's determination to protect and care for Lean on Pete as they embark on a journey of survival and self-discovery. The film highlights how horses can serve as sources of solace and companionship in difficult times. It also delves into the idea that the unconditional love and loyalty of a horse can provide a lifeline in the face of adversity.

An abandoned zebra grows up believing he is a racehorse, and, with the help of his barnyard friends and a teenage girl, sets out to achieve his dream of racing with thoroughbreds.

Racing Stripes is a family comedy film that tells the story of a young zebra named Stripes who aspires to become a racehorse. The movie explores themes of perseverance, identity, and the importance of believing in oneself. It portrays Stripes' journey as he defies expectations and follows his dream of racing alongside thoroughbred horses. The film emphasizes the value of diversity and inclusion in the world of horse racing, showcasing how differences can be strengths. It highlights the idea that horses, regardless of their appearance, can achieve greatness with the right support and determination.

After a near-fatal accident, on a horse the experts thought was nothing special, a determined rider from the wrong side of the tracks defies all the odds to pursue her dreams of winning a national jumping championship.

A Sunday Horse is a biographical drama based on the true story of Debi Walden, a young rider with a dream of becoming a champion show jumper. The film explores themes of perseverance, resilience, and the pursuit of excellence in equestrian sports. It portrays Debi's unwavering dedication to her horse and her determination to overcome obstacles on her path to success. The movie underscores the idea that the bond between a rider and their horse is built on hard work, trust, and a shared commitment to reaching the pinnacle of their sport. It celebrates the achievements of equestrian athletes and the role of horses in their journey to excellence.

The Derby Stallion is a coming-of-age film that follows the story of a teenage boy named Patrick who forms a bond with a retired racehorse named Shergar. The movie explores themes of friendship, responsibility, and the transformative power of horses. It portrays how Patrick's involvement with Shergar leads to personal growth and a deeper understanding of life's challenges. The film underscores the idea that horses can teach valuable life lessons and provide a sense of purpose to individuals, especially young people facing the complexities of adolescence.

Dark Horse is a documentary film that tells the remarkable true story of a group of working-class people from a small Welsh village who come together to breed and race a champion racehorse named Dream Alliance. The film explores themes of community, hope, and the pursuit of a dream against all odds. It portrays how the villagers, led by Jan Vokes, invest their time, money, and love into the horse, defying societal expectations. The documentary highlights the idea that horses can serve as symbols of hope and unity within a community, transcending economic barriers and offering a sense of belonging and pride.
